If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. title: angel artwork elgin cooper park dropped
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. title: coronavirus in scotland here are the key demographics
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. title: scotland cricket t20 world cup exposure
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. title: scotland autumn series 2021 fans right to have big expectations believes finn russell
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 5 2021
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowCaring for the carersThroughout the hardships and challenges of the pandemic, carers have become valued members of families who could barely have survived without them.Providing care for a person in their own home can be le-changing, offering them safety, independence and companionship.There can be few more vital roles to be played in society but are these invaluable people not themselves being supported Caring for the carers by investing in their teams, their working conditions and their pay must be the first priority of the mooted National Care Service, and in the meantime urgent action is needed to attract and retain staff in these crucial roles.When somebody chooses to train for this dficult, but hugely rewarding, career they should feel safe in the knowledge that they will be supported, paid a good wage and not be forced by shortages to offer anything other than the high quality, professional service they so badly want to deliver.RemembranceFor a hundred years communities across the UK have come together to honour all who have lost their lives in wars and military campaigns.These precious acts of remembrance were curtailed last year due to Covid restrictions, so perhaps this year it is more important than ever to head out to churches and cenotaphs all around our community, and together we will remember them.

title: alexander-mccall-smith-gavin-hastings-appearing-today
story: The Baillie Gford Borders Book Festival is taking place this week at Abbotsford House and tickets are still available to buy from the Box Office as well as online.This yearrsquos Festival sees a host of big names from politics, sport, history, crime and current affairs in more than  live events over six days at the home of Sir Walter Scott from November -.And visitors need not worry all Government Covid- guidelines will be strictly adhered to, without detracting from the sense of excitement.These are the shows available today At : Storytelling the Super Power Agency Way! Will take place at the McInroy  Wood Marquee. Tickets poundAlso at : Kristina Stephenson: The Museum of Marvellous Things will appear at the Sir Walter Scott Marquee. Tickets poundAt : Pamela Butchart will appear at the McInroy  Wood Marquee. Tickets poundAt : Alexander McCall Smith will appear at the Sir Walter Scott Marquee. title: not-take-rugby-match-borders
story: Another feast of live rugby is taking place in the region and beyond this weekend including a Premiership Borders derby between Selkirk and Jed-Forest at Philiphaugh. Elsewhere Hawick travel to league leaders Currie.In National League Division One Gala will take the long trip to face Highland, Melrose host Ayr, Kelso are in the capital to meet Watsonians and Biggar host Boroughmuir at Hartree Mill.In National League Division Two Peebles welcome Glasgow Accies.In National League Division Three Berwick host Strathmore.In National East League One Duns host Linlithgow.In National East League Two Hawick Linden have a home game against Livingston.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League One Hawick Force have an away game at Currie A whilst Selkirk A host Jed-Forest A.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League Two Gala A are away to Linlithgow A, Melrose Storm host Watsonians A and Peebles Reds take on Kelso Sharks at the Gytes.In the Semi-Junior Border League Jed Thistle host Tynedale Colts, Selkirk Youth are at home to Carlisle Colts, Kelso Harlequins take on Hawick Youth at Poynder Park, Melrose Wasps host a Borders derby against Gala Wanderers at the Greenyards and Peebles Colts welcome Duns Colts.On Sunday Scotland take on Australia in the second game of the Autumn Series at BT Murrayfield. Kick off .pm

title: peeblesshire-woman-ran-marathon-memory-beautiful-mum
story: A BORDERS woman completed the London Marathon in memory of her "beautul mum" who passed away following a battle with cancer.Fiona Kennedy, from Peebles, ran her first marathon in  to mark her mother completing  years of treatment for soft tissue cancer and to raise money for Sarcoma UK ndash the charity which had supported her mum throughout her treatment.After completing the Edinburgh race in May  and raising pound,, Fionas mum passed away at the age of  in September ."Mumrsquos ethos meant that she took the years of surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and drug trials in her stride," said Fiona. "She continued to travel, play an active part in her grandchildrenrsquos lives and was a much-loved we, mum, sister, and aunt.":Feast of live rugby available for fans in the Borders this weekendAlthough shed sworn to never run again, Fiona, her aunt, uncle and cousins agreed to run a marathon in her mums memory.The family promptly signed up to run the London Marathon  for Sarcoma UK.However, the coronavirus pandemic meant last years marathon was postponed.But despite lockdown, Fiona continued to train for when the marathon was rearranged for October this year.:Man threatened to kill his partner during a bust-up in the Borders"I swore I would never run again after Edinburgh and I crossed the line in London two years later having raised a further pound, for Sarcoma UK," said Fiona."I have been out running in my finishers t-shirt twice since completing London, and I have felt a real sense of accomplishment pounding the pavements in that prestigious t-shirt."Crossing the finish line was a huge sense of relief."My cousin Lucy and I crossed it together hand in hand and promptly burst into tears."The sense of achievement was felt immediately, not least because the staff, marshals and volunteers were amazing in their support and care."The congratulations came from runners, supports and strangers..remove"Mum wasnrsquot at the finish line in London but Irsquom sure she would have been amazed and proud in equal measures.":Photo Gallery: Some of the best Halloween costumes from across the BordersFiona is now looking forward to ing to sports she enjoys, but can also see herself joining in park runs.She said: "I am looking forward to ing to other forms of exercise that I love, but I do see myself factoring in the odd Parkrun to tick my legs over."In terms of fundraising ndash I will have a lelong affiliation with Sarcoma UK."Mum wanted to do more in terms of contributing to research, raising awareness and rising funds, and this is a duty I have inherited."I will continue to look for ways to support the charity I have such fondness for."

title: peebles-choir-appoints-new-musical-director
story: A BORDERS choir has welcomed its new musical director.Peebles-based choir InChorus said it is ldquodelighted to welcome Au Arias to the choir.Au, who is originally from Argentina, has worked with choirs and orchestras in five countries and worked in Turkey for three years as opera director at the Samsun State Opera and Ballet before moving to Scotland with his we last year.Au said: ldquoI have always been interested in big choirs and am very happy to be given the opportunity to work with InChorus in this lovely Borders town.ldquoDespite the many months of being unable to sing together I am amazed at their ability and determination to sound good.The choir spent a number of months without a musical director as the coronavirus pandemic limited opportunities to meet with candidates.Choir manager Cath Shepheard said: ldquoInChorus had been without an MD for some months because the pandemic restrictions prevented our large choir meeting potential candidates in person.ldquoWe thank Au for his patience in waiting for us, and are very pleased that he is with us now.InChorus willto singing for audiences this winter with a performance at this yearrsquos Peebles Christmas Lights Switch On on Sunday, November .They will then sing at Pentland Plants in Edinburgh on December  and at Jupiter Artland Christmas Fair on Sunday, December .Au added: ldquoI have encouraged the choir to take part in some Christmas events to build our performance confidence.ldquoAfter that we will be working on something dferent.ldquoInChorus prides itself in being open to new musical experiences and I intend to give them that.To find out more about InChorus, including how to join the choir, contact Cath at: manager@inchoruschoir, through the website on www.inchoruschoir, on Facebook or Twitter.

title: enrolment-week-parents-apply-borders-school-places
story: PARENTS are invited to register their children for a school place for August  during enrolment week.From November -, parents of any child who is five years old before February ,  can fill in an online application.They will need to have electronic copies of their childrsquos birth certicate and proof of address available to upload along with their application.They should then make contact with their local primary school to confirm the application has been made.Parents of a child whose fth birthday falls between August ,  and February ,  have the right to defer their childrsquos entry to primary school.Applications for deferred entry should be discussed with the head teacher or early learning and childcare setting manager.Any parent intending to make a placement request for their child at a school other than their local catchment school should enrol with their local school in the normal way using the online form.They should also contact their preferred school and complete the online placement request form, available online at: www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolenrolment from November .Children who are moving from primary to secondary school in August  will receive details of the local catchment school from their current primary school.Early learning and childcareenrolment week for three and four year olds will take place from January - .Councillor Carol Hamilton, executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoParents of any child due to start Primary  are asked to complete the online form that will be available during enrolment week.ldquoThe online process is one that was introduced as part of our response to the pandemic and we hope parents continue to find helpful and straightforward.More information about the enrolment process is available at: www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolenrolment or on   or at: hqoperations@scotborders.gov.uk

title: scott-brash-statue-plans-monument-add-new-dimension
story: THE Olympic legacy of Scott Brash, which was honoured with the erection of a statue, could soon be illuminated with a golden glow.The showjumper landed back in Peebles to unveil the lesize sculpture in recognition of his gold medal back in .The tribute to one of the regionrsquos greatest ever sportsmen was warmly welcomed by the community, and is a spectacular vision on entry to the town from Edinburgh Road.The project was the brainwave of voluntary group Bonnie Peebles, which commissioned the sculpture, which artist Kevin Paxon designed and created from recycled horseshoes.Now, community leaders would like to highlight his golden glory further and hope to work with Bonnie Peebles to clear the final hurdle in this project.During a meeting of Peebles Community Council, members discussed installing lighting at the monument. It was suggested that solar-powered lights would be the most cost-effective option.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler said an application to fund the lighting could be submitted to the Peebles Parking Fees Fund.Chairman Les Turnbull said: ldquoThe Scott Brash monument is a wonderfully impressive artwork at the gateway to the town.ldquoTo have it lit would add another dimension for us all to enjoy, particularly as the nights draw in.

title: sbc-place-making-priority-list-questioned-meeting
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilrisks annoying communities not on a list of suggested lsquopriorityrsquo areas for initial support, a meeting has been told.lsquoPlace-makingrsquo ndash an initiative which aims to ldquotransform the working relationship between the council and communities ndash was discussed at a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership on Tuesday .At the virtual gathering, SBC programme officer James Lamb said that place-making is ldquoall about involving local people in the place that they live and identying their needs and priorities, working out an action plan that addresses those and starting to implement projects.Innerleithen and Walkerburn are the two lsquoTweeddalersquo areas selected on a potential shortlist for ldquoinitial place-making activity created by council officers.On the suggested priority areas, Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, of the SNP, said the council should ldquofocus on those communities that have initiative and want to take initiative.He added: ldquoIn terms of assessing communities, I think we should bin the list thatrsquos in front of us becauseI was in Tweeddale West - Eddleston, Carlops, West Linton, Brouhgton or Skirling - I would be less than pleased that I didnrsquot see my community appearing on that list andI was in Tweeddale East - in Cardrona or Clovenfords - Irsquod also be p***** off.Earlier in the meeting, Tweeddale West councillor Heather Anderson, also of the SNP, said that place-making should ldquostart from the bottom up rather than from a list.ldquoThis is about communities leading on how we draft a locality plan for the Borders, so instead of us drafting a locality plan and consulting communities wersquore trying to say, lsquoYou write the plan and wersquoll assimilate up the way.rsquoldquoThis [list] is tending towards, lsquoWhere are the needs and deficiencies rsquo instead of, lsquoWhere are the communities that are bursting with ideas and enthusiasm, ready to get going to make a change rsquo.removeldquoThey will teach the other communities the benefit of the engagement. Itrsquos coming from them and wersquore picking up on their energy, rather than assessing them to see whether or not they fit the criteria for us to work with them.Mr Lamb said the list was ldquojust a suggestion but said that Ms Andersonrsquos proposal could be a ldquogreat approach.On Ms Andersonrsquos suggestion, Tweeddale East councillor Shona Haslam, of the Conservatives, said: ldquoMy only concern is that wersquoll end up prioritising communities already doing a lot and attracting a lot of funding. While I understand and support the concept of demonstrating best practice and allowing that to trickle through, perhaps we should look at a model of linking up communities, so a community that isnrsquot doing very well with one that is doing well in a mentoring programme.ldquoI worry slightly that itrsquoll be Newcastleton that gets everything because Newcastleton are extremely good at having lots of community projects and attracting a lot of community funding.ldquoI would be slightly anxious going down that route full throttle.The council leader added: ldquoI donrsquot want anyone to be left behind or just the usual suspects to be getting the support.Ms Anderson, who supported Mrs Haslamrsquos comments, said: ldquoWe can get somewhere with thiswe shake it about a bit.

title: sbc-first-local-authority-scotland-use-road-surface
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is the first local authority in Scotland to use a road surface which is expected to improve durability, a meeting has heard.The surface course specication, TS, is also skid resistant, according to council officer Donald Scott.Mr Scott told a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership on Tuesdaythat TS had previously only been used on trunk roads, with the council the first in the country to try it on a rural network.He also gave an update on the Pothole Pro, trialled by the local authority earlier this year.ldquoWe hope it will be here early next year, said Mr Scott. ldquoWersquore reviewing the best way to deliver that.The JCB machine claims to fix potholes four times quicker than normal ndash and at half the cost.Member of the public Neil McCarroll asked Mr Scott about the standard of repairs, adding that the ldquosame potholes need repairing every year.Mr Scott explained that potholes are split into dferent categories which need to be temporarily dealt with within a certain period of time.ldquoItrsquos very dficult to carry out permanent repairs on seven and -day defects becausewe started to carry out permanent repairs on those we wouldnrsquot get round the network, he said.Temporary repairs are usually carried out by the councilrsquos in-house contractor, but the local authority brought in external contractors in the last financial year ldquobecause of the number of potholes on the network, according to Mr Scott.

title: free-bus-travel-22s-january-says-borders-msp
story: UNDER s will be able to ride the bus for free from January, according to a Borders MSP.Christine Grahame, Holyrood representative for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said the announcement will help to meet a key manesto pledge by the SNP in the May elections.Those under the age of  in the Borders will benefit from free bus travel from January .On the announcement, Ms Grahame, of the SNP, said: ldquoThe SNP Scottish Government is once again making an investment in our young peoplersquos future. By making bus travel free for under s in the Borders and across Scotland, opportunities for young people to work, travel and study are being opened up for them.ldquoTravelling by bus is one of the most environmentally friendly ways to get across the country and research shows that young people recognise the vital role public transport will play in hitting our climate change targets.ldquoThis move will not only be vital in our journey to net zero, but will also take pressure off young people and their familiesrsquo finances.

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Scotlandwill play Australia in their second match of the rugby autumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotland v Australia match this weekend The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at .pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v Australiaand how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at .pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland team line-up Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: treat-chamber-music-fans-peebles
story: GAIA Duo, Chamber Music Scotlands Ensemble in Residence -, end their Scottish tour at the Eastgate Theatre, Peebles on Tuesday th November at .pm, presented by Music in Peebles.Katrina Lee, a violinist from Yorkshire and Alice Allen, a cellist from Banchory, formed their musical duo partnership  years ago, and have consolidated it during their two years with Chamber Music Scotland, working with artists and composers to forge new works, and to research Scottish female composers hitherto unknown, to bring their music to light.Their programme showcases composers spanning  years including Catherine White Sonata , Ignatius Sancho Selection of Dances, Rebecca Clarke Lullaby and Grotesque, Elizabeth Maconchy Theme and Variations plus works by Sally Beamish and Duncan Strachan commissioned for GAIA.Catherine Whitersquos Sonata was published in Edinburgh as part of a collection by ldquoA Young Lady. Rebecca ClarkeBritish-American, was a virtuoso viola player whose compositions were judged, at the time, ldquotoo beautul to have been written by a woman, and she felt too discouraged to write more.Elizabeth Maconchy,British-Irish, is considered to be one of Britainrsquos finest th century composers with a prolic output, but, as usual, not so well-known yet. Ignatius Sancho was born on a slave ship in  and had a remarkable le.Katrina and Alice are changing the music scene already with their fresh ideas and innovative projects. Both are multi-award winning musicians, are members of several ensembles, and have commissioned several new exciting pieces from Scottish young composers.For more information about these exciting new chamber musicians, please see their website https:www.gaiaduoTickets for th November pound, Discounts pound, Students under  FREEFor information about this th Season concerts please see https:musicinpeebles.org.uk

title: peebles-facilitator-honoured-winning-international-prize
story: A WOMAN from the Borders is celebrating after receiving ldquoglobal recognition by winning an award.Joyce Matthews, who runs her own global facilitation business, won the award for her work developing school leaders with North Ayrshire Council.The ldquoprestigious competition is organised annually by the International Association of Facilitatorsto ldquorecognise the power of facilitation worldwide.ldquoTo be able to challenge the status quo and change the way leadership development has always been done, is empowering for everyone involved, said Mrs Matthews, of Peebles.ldquoIrsquom honoured to receive global recognition for the work I do.:Free bus travel for under s in the Borders from January, says MSPThe Facilitation Impact Awards honour organisations and the people in them that have used facilitation to achieve a measurable and positive impact.Despite a global pandemic, the processes Mrs Matthews put in place with North Ayrshirersquos leadership development workstream meant that the organisation saved thousands of pounds while building a self-sustaining leadership model which reduces the need for external consultants and presenters.A high percentage of teachers who trained as facilitators have now been promoted, demonstrating the improvement of skills and competence of the leaders who have participated in the programme.Andrew McClelland, head of education service, said: ldquoOur work on leadership development and professional learning is sector-leading due to the focus on continual improvement for our own people, by our own people.ldquoWe have made signicant progress in the last  months and are proud to share this work widely.:Peeblesshire woman ran marathon in memory of her "beautul mum"All winners, selected by a global  of facilitation experts, demonstrated the range of projects the skills of a professional facilitator can be used for.Sixteen organisations spanning Belgium, Canada, China, India, Iran, Ireland, the Philippines, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Scotland, South Africa, Switzerland, Taiwan and the United States were recognised for using facilitation to make change and progress happen for their organisations..removeMrs Matthews and the team at North Ayrshire were the only UK recipients of an award.ldquoThe remarkably erse range of projects receiving awards demonstrates our belief that good group process facilitation can be used in any context to help people change the world around them and have an impact, said Vinay Kumar, chair of the IAF.ldquoThe facilitators who have gained recognition for their expertise have combined innovative planning with expert delivery in widely-ied fields to help their clients meet complex challenges and achieve organisational objectives.

title: scots-women-take-japan-dam-health-stadium-sunday
story: BORDERS trio Lana Skeldon, Lisa Thomson and Chloe Rollie have been named in Scotland Women Head Coach Bryan Eassonrsquos -player squad for the upcoming Autumn Test against Japan at the DAM Health Stadiumndash live on BBC ALBA.If they play Skeldon will collect her th cap, Thomson will pick up her th cap Rollie will get her th cap.Easson said: ldquoThe upcoming Autumn Test against Japan is a great opportunity for us to learn from our experience in the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers.ldquoJapan have recently qualied for the Rugby World Cup as the highest ranked team in the Asia qualication process so this will be an ideal test for us as it exposes us to a dferent opponent and playing style ahead of our final qualication tournament next year."The players are also excited to run out in front of a home crowd for the first time since , especially as theyve played mostly behind closed doors for the past  months. Weve all hugely missed having crowds so itll be fantastic to have supporters along at the DAM Health Stadium to cheer the players on."Scotlandrsquos last encounter against the Brave Blossoms was in November , which was also the last match they played in front of a home crowd, with Japan taking the spoils that day with a - win.Eassonrsquos squad recently kept their World Cup ambitions in sight following two back-to-back wins against Spain and Ireland during the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers in Parma.The sidersquos recent success has also seen them rise to an all-time high of ninth in the Womenrsquos World Rugby rankings.Forwards: Leah Bartlett , Christine Belisle , Sarah Bonar , Lisa Cockburn , Evie Gallagher , Jade Konkel , Rachel Malcolm , Rachel McLachlan , Louise McMillan , Lyndsay OrsquoDonnell , Lana Skeldon , Emma Wassell , Molly Wright , Anne Young .removeBacks: Shona Campbell , Megan Gaffney , Sarah Law , Rhona Lloyd , Jenny Maxwell , Holly McIntyre , Helen Nelson , Chloe Rollie , Hannah Smith , Meryl Smith , Lisa ThomsonEvie Wills Tickets for Scotland Women v Japan Women are on sale via the SRU website.Kids for pound tickets are available with a paying adult, at pound, and Us go for pound.

title: peeblesshire-projects-get-cash-part-recovery-scheme
story: TWO Peeblesshire organisations have won funding after successful applications to a council grant scheme.St Ronanrsquos Silver Band will be awarded more than pound, from the Build Back a Better Borders Recovery Fund, while the Walkerburn Bowling and Petanque Club will receive around pound,.However, the Tweeddale Rideability Group was unsuccessful in a bid for more than pound,.On the St Ronanrsquos Silver Band application, a Scottish Borders Council report states: ldquoSt Ronanrsquos would like to purchase  pBuzz instruments and pay for tuition time to provide  children with access to free face to face musical tuition.ldquopBuzz instruments have been designed to encourage children to learn a musical instrument.ldquoTwo -week blocks of tuition will be delivered to  children by a qualied teacher.ldquoThe hope is that this training programme will encourage children to progress to a traditional brass instrument, addressing the bandrsquos gap in recruitment and helping make the band more sustainable.The report adds: ldquoIn addition, St Ronanrsquos Silver Band are seeking funding for the installation of new windows and blinds to their hall as well as the purchase and installation of a new shed.ldquoThe band hall is not currently being used for rehearsals as the windows do not open safely. The band would like to replace the windows with UPVC windows which will allow them to open the windows for the required ventilation following COVID-.Meanwhile, the Walkerburn Bowling and Petanque Club hopes to use the funding to ldquocreate a childrenrsquos practice area and to build a better retaining wall alongside the road.The report adds: ldquoThe club would like to open the club up to more members and improve the disabled facilities. The petanque area has been expanded and is now more user friendly, but better disabled access is needed ndash especially for wheelchair users.ldquoThe club needs to build a level walkway from the clubhouse to the street and to have a better pathway for wheelchairs to negotiate. They would also like to create a childrenrsquos practice area and build a better retaining wall alongside the road. The current wall is in a state of disrepair..removeHowever, the Tweeddale Rideability Grouprsquos application has not been approved.The group wanted to use the money to buy a horse, with the price of new horses ldquogreatly increasing during the pandemic.ldquoThis means where previously costs would have been in the region of pound, to pound, groups iniduals can now expect to pay pound, to pound,, a report states.But the bid was refused due to it failing to demonstrate ldquothe new element of the application.ldquoThe application is looking at continuing a service and succession planning due to the age of current horses as opposed to delivering something new, the report explains.During a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership, Scottish Borders Council officer Kenny Harrow said the group could apply to the community fund as it ldquomight be a better fit.

title: exciting-competition-young-artists-borders
story: BUDDING young artists in the Borders will have the chance to reimagine the facade of Kelso Town Hall.The best designs will be projected onto the building, for two spectacular nights in February between Saturday th and Saturday th, alongside artwork from Borders Art Fair participating artists.A selection of the designs will also be exhibited at the Borders Art Fair in March.This competition is open to all young people, up to, and including, the age of , who live or, go to school in, the Scottish Borders.There will be prizes for the best entries, according to age groups: under s, -s and  years and over.Digital designs should be sent to info@bordersartfairDesigns on paper can be posted to Border Arts Development, Kirkmains Farm, Jedburgh TD TP or scanned and emailed to info@bordersartfair.Moving image designs should be no longer than  secondsPlease include your name, age, address, email address or phone numberApplicants under  must get consent from their parent or legalbefore entering the competition. This competition is free to enter and no purchase is necessaryBorder Arts Development C.I.C. must receive entries by .pm on Monday th December .A template is available as a starting point for and can be downloaded via https:www.bordersartfair
